sn35.23:1.2: While most teaching templates are shared between the six senses and the aggregates, only the six senses are declared to be the “all”. This is because the six senses cover the entirety of experience, whereas the aggregates select the aspects most prominently grasped as self. For context, see SN 35.28 and notes.
sn35.23:1.7: The “someone” would be a philosopher of the Upaniṣads, for whom the metaphysical notion of “all” is crucial. The same phrasing is used of the rejection of the “duality” of the senses; see SN 35.92 and notes.
sn35.23:1.11: The brahmins of the Upaniṣads show off their rhetorical prowess through elevated debates. These debates, however, are exceedingly specialized, making sense only for those steeped in Vedic culture and ritual.
